2. API Overview¶

This section provides an overview of StaticFrame components and features.

Throughout this section significant differences from Pandas will be called out. As Pandas has made numerous changes to its API over the years, no attempt will be made to isolate what versions of Pandas implement various functionality. Instead, reference will only be made to “versions” of Pandas.

2.1. Structures¶

2.1.1. Primary Containers¶

The primary components of the StaticFrame library are the 1D Series and the 2D Frame and FrameGO.

class Series(values, *, index=None, dtype=None, own_index=False)[source]¶

A one-dimensional ordered, labelled collection, immutable and of fixed size.

class Frame(data=None, *, index=None, columns=None, own_data: bool = False, own_index: bool = False, own_columns: bool = False)[source]¶

A two-dimensional ordered, labelled collection, immutable and of fixed size.

class FrameGO(data=None, *, index=None, columns=None, own_data: bool = False, own_index: bool = False, own_columns: bool = False)[source]¶

A two-dimensional ordered, labelled collection, immutable with grow-only columns.

2.1.2. Index Mappings¶

Index mapping classes are used to map labels to ordinal positions on the Series, Frame, and FrameGO.

class Index(labels: typing.Generator[[collections.abc.Hashable, NoneType], NoneType], loc_is_iloc: bool = False)[source]¶

A mapping of labels to positions, immutable and of fixed size. Used in Series and as index and columns in Frame.

Parameters:
  • labels – the ordered keys to use as the index; can be a generator
  • loc_is_iloc – optimization for when a contiguous integer idnex is provided as labels.
class IndexGO(labels: typing.Generator[[collections.abc.Hashable, NoneType], NoneType], loc_is_iloc: bool = False)[source]¶

A mapping of labels to positions, immutable with grow-only size. Used as columns in FrameGO.

Deviations from Pandas

Index and IndexGO require that all labels are unique. Duplicated labels will raise an error in all cases. This deviates form Pandas, where Index objects permit duplicate labels. This also makes options like the verify_integrity argument to pd.Series.set_index and pd.DataFrame.set_index unnecessary.

2.1.3. Utility Objects¶

class TypeBlocks(*, blocks: typing.Iterable[numpy.ndarray], dtypes: typing.Iterable[numpy.dtype], index: typing.Iterable[typing.Tuple[int, int]], shape: typing.Tuple[int, int])[source]¶

An ordered collection of potentially heterogenous, immutable NumPy arrays, providing an external array-like interface of a single, 2D array. Used by Frame for core, unindexed array management.

class IterNode(*, container: typing.Union[package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series, typing.Frame], function_values, function_items, yield_type: package.public.static_frame.static_frame.IterNodeType, apply_type: package.public.static_frame.static_frame.IterNodeApplyType = <IterNodeApplyType.SERIES_ITEMS: 1>)[source]¶

Iterface to a type of iteration on Series and Frame.

class IterNodeDelegate(func_values, func_items, yield_type: package.public.static_frame.static_frame.IterNodeType, apply_constructor)[source]¶

Delegate returned from IterNode, providing iteration as well as a family of apply methods.

2.2. Container Import and Creation¶

Both Series and Frame have from_items constructors that consume keyvalue pairs, such as returned by dict.items() and similar functions.

2.2.1. Series¶

classmethod Series.from_items(pairs, dtype=None) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Series constructor from an iterator or generator of pairs, where the first value is the index and the second value is the value.

2.2.2. Frame¶

classmethod Frame.from_items(pairs, *, index=None)[source]¶

Frame constructor from an iterator or generator of pairs, where the first value is the column name and the second value an iterable of column values.

classmethod Frame.from_records(records, *, index, columns)[source]¶

Frame constructor from an iterable of rows.

Parameters:
  • records – Iterable of row values.
  • index – Iterable of index labels, equal in length to the number of records.
  • columns – Iterable of column labels, equal in length to the length of each row.s
classmethod Frame.from_concat(frames: typing.Iterable[typing.Frame], axis: int = 0, union=True, index=None, columns=None)[source]¶

Concatenate multiple Frames into a new Frame. If index or columns are provided and appropriately sized, the resulting Frame will have those indices. If the axis along concatenation (index for axis 0, columns for axis 1) is unique after concatenation, it will be preserved.

Parameters:
  • frames – Iterable of Frames.
  • axis – 0 stacks vertically, 1 stacks horizontally
classmethod Frame.from_csv(fp: typing.Union[str, _io.StringIO, _io.BytesIO], *, sep: str = ',', index_column: typing.Union[int, str, NoneType] = None, skip_header: int = 0, skip_footer: int = 0, header_is_columns: bool = True, dtype=None, encoding: typing.Union[str, NoneType] = None) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶
Parameters:
  • header_is_columns – if True, field names are read from the first line after the first skip_header lines
  • dtype – set to None by default to permit discovery
classmethod Frame.from_tsv(fp, **kwargs)[source]¶

2.3. Dictionary-Like Interface¶

Series and Frame provide dictionary-like interfaces.

For more flexible iteration of rows or columns, see Iterators below.

2.3.1. Series¶

Series.keys() → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Index[source]¶

Iterator of index labels.

Series.__iter__()[source]¶

Iterator of index labels, same as Series.keys().

Series.__contains__(value) → bool[source]¶

Inclusion of value in index labels.

Series.values¶

1D NumPy array of values

Series.items() → typing.Generator[[typing.Tuple[typing.Any, typing.Any], NoneType], NoneType][source]¶

Iterator of pairs of index label and value.

Series.__len__() → int[source]¶

Length of values.

Series.get(key, default=None)[source]¶

Return the value found at the index key, else the default if the key is not found.

2.3.2. Frame¶

Frame.keys()[source]¶

Iterator of column labels.

Frame.__iter__()[source]¶

Iterator of column labels, same as Frame.keys().

Frame.__contains__(value) → bool[source]¶

Inclusion of value in column labels.

Frame.values¶

2D NumPy array of Frame values

Frame.items() → typing.Generator[[typing.Tuple[typing.Any, package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series], NoneType], NoneType][source]¶

Iterator of pairs of column label and corresponding column Series.

Frame.__len__() → int[source]¶

Length of rows in values.

Frame.get(key, default=None)[source]¶

Return the value found at the columns key, else the default if the key is not found.

Deviations from Pandas

For consistency, the iterator returned by Series.keys() and Frame.keys() is the same as the iterator returned by iterating the object itself. This deviates from Pandas, where iterating a Series iterates pd.Series.values while iterating a DataFrame iterates pd.DataFrame.keys().

2.4. Operators¶

Series, Frame, and Index, as well as their derived classes, provide support for the full range of operators available with NumPy. In addition, Series and Frame feature index-alignment and automatic index expansion when both opperands are StaticFrame objects.

2.4.1. Series¶

Series.__add__(other)¶
Series.__sub__(other)¶

2.4.2. Frame¶

Frame.__add__(other)¶
Frame.__sub__(other)¶

Deviations from Pandas

For consistency in operator application and to insure index alignment, all operators return an union index when both opperrands are StaticFrame containers. This deviates from Pandas, where in some versions equality operators did not align on a union index, and behaved differently than other operators.

2.5. Index Manipulation¶

2.5.1. Index¶

Index.relabel(mapper: typing.Union[typing.Callable, typing.Mapping]) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Index[source]¶

Return a new Index with labels replaced by the callable or mapping; order will be retained. If a mapping is used, the mapping need not map all origin keys.

2.5.2. Series¶

Series.relabel(mapper: typing.Union[typing.Callable, typing.Mapping]) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return a new Series based on a mapping (or callable) from old to new index values.

Series.reindex(index: typing.Union[package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Index, typing.Sequence[typing.Any]], fill_value=nan) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return a new Series based on the passed index.

Parameters:fill_value – attempted to be used, but may be coerced by the dtype of this Series. `

2.5.3. Frame¶

Frame.relabel(index: typing.Union[typing.Callable, typing.Mapping] = None, columns: typing.Union[typing.Callable, typing.Mapping] = None) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a new Series based on a mapping (or callable) from old to new index values.

Frame.reindex(index: typing.Union[package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Index, typing.Sequence[typing.Any]] = None, columns: typing.Union[package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Index, typing.Sequence[typing.Any]] = None, fill_value=nan) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a new Frame based on the passed index and/or columns.

Deviations from Pandas

The Pandas pd.DataFrame.rename()

2.6. Iterators¶

Both Series and Frame offer a variety of iterators (all generators) for flexible transversal of axis and values. In addition, all iterators have a family of apply methods for applying functions to the values iterated.

2.6.1. Element Iterators¶

2.6.1.1. Series¶

Series.iter_element()¶
Series.iter_element_items()¶

Deviations from Pandas

The functionality of Pandas pd.Series.map() and pd.Series.apply() can both be obtained with Series.iter_element().apply(). When given a mapping, Series.iter_element().apply() will pass original values unchanged if they are not found in the mapping. This deviates from pd.Series.map(), which fills unmapped values with NaN.

2.6.1.2. Frame¶

Frame.iter_element()¶
Frame.iter_element_items()¶

Deviations from Pandas

The functionality of Pandas pd.DataFrame.applymap() can be obtained with Frame.iter_element().apply(), though the latter accepts both callables and mapping objects.

2.6.2. Axis Iterators¶

Frame.iter_array()¶
Frame.iter_array_items()¶
Frame.iter_tuple()¶
Frame.iter_tuple_items()¶
Frame.iter_series()¶
Frame.iter_series_items()¶

Deviations from Pandas

The functionality of Pandas pd.DataFrame.itertuples() can be obtained with Frame.iter_tuple(axis=0). The functionality of Pandas pd.DataFrame.iterrows() can be obtained with Frame.iter_series(axis=0). The functionality of Pandas pd.DataFrame.iteritems() can be obtained with Frame.iter_series_items(axis=1). The functionality of Pandas pd.DataFrame.apply(axis) can be obtained with Frame.iter_series(axis).apply().

2.6.3. Group Iterators¶

2.6.3.1. Series¶

Series.iter_group()¶

Iterator of groups of unique values (in Series).

Series.iter_group_items()¶

Iterator of pairs of group and grouped values (in a Series).

2.6.3.2. Frame¶

Frame.iter_group(key, axis=0)¶

Iterate over groups (in Frames) based on unique values selected with key. If axis is 0, subgroups of rows are retuned and key selects columns; If axis is 1, subgroups of columns are returned and key selects rows.

Frame.iter_group_items(key, axis=0)¶

Iterator of pairs of group and grouped values (in a Frame).

2.7. Function Application to Iterators¶

Frame and Series return IterNodeDelegate instances when called. These instances are prepared for iteation via IterNodeDelegate.__iter__(), and in addition, have a number of methods for function application.

IterNodeDelegate.__iter__()[source]¶

Return a generator based on the yield type.

IterNodeDelegate.apply(func: typing.Union[typing.Callable, typing.Mapping], dtype=None, max_workers=None, chunksize=20, use_threads=False) → typing.Union[package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series, typing.Frame][source]¶

Apply passed function to each object iterated, where the object depends on the creation of this instance.

IterNodeDelegate.apply_iter(func: typing.Union[typing.Callable, typing.Mapping], dtype=None) → typing.Generator[[typing.Any, NoneType], NoneType][source]¶

Generator that applies the passed function to each element iterated and yields the result.

IterNodeDelegate.apply_iter_items(func: typing.Union[typing.Callable, typing.Mapping]) → typing.Generator[[typing.Tuple[typing.Any, typing.Any], NoneType], NoneType][source]¶

Generator that applies function to each element iterated and yields the pair of element and the result.

Parameters:func – A function or a mapping object that defines __getitem__ and __contains__. If a mpping is given and a value is not found in the mapping, the value is returned unchanged (this deviates from Pandas Series.map, which inserts NaNs)

2.8. Assignment¶

Series and Frame provide asign-to-copy interfaces, permitting assignment with slices similar to Pandas and Numpy.

2.8.1. Series¶

Series.assign[key](value)
Series.assign.loc[key](value)
Series.assign.iloc[key](value)

2.8.2. Frame¶

2.9. Missing Value Handling¶

Series and Frame provide covnient funcions for finding, dropping, and replacing missing values. In the tradition of Pandas, NaN and None values are treated as both missing, regardless of the dtype in which they are contained.

2.9.1. Series¶

Series.isna() → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return a same-indexed, Boolean Series indicating which values are NaN or None.

Series.notna() → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return a same-indexed, Boolean Series indicating which values are NaN or None.

Series.dropna() → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return a new Series after removing values of NaN or None.

Series.fillna(value) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return a new Series after replacing NaN or None values with the supplied value.

2.9.2. Frame¶

Frame.isna() → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a same-indexed, Boolean Frame indicating True which values are NaN or None.

Frame.notna() → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a same-indexed, Boolean Frame indicating True which values are not NaN or None.

Frame.dropna(axis: int = 0, condition: typing.Callable[[numpy.ndarray], bool] = <function all>) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a new Frame after removing rows (axis 0) or columns (axis 1) where condition is True, where condition is an NumPy ufunc that process the Boolean array returned by isna().

Frame.fillna(value) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a new Frame after replacing NaN or None values with the supplied value.

Deviations from Pandas

dropna() takes a condition argument, which is a NumPy ufunc that accepts an axis argument. This differs from Pandas how argument. A how of “all” is equivalent to a condition of np.all; A how of “any” is equivalent to a condition of np.any.

2.10. Sorting¶

Index, Series and Frame provide sorting. In all cases, a new object is returned.

2.10.1. Index¶

Index.sort(ascending: bool = True, kind: str = 'mergesort') → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Index[source]¶

Return a new Index with the labels sorted.

Parameters:kind – Sort algorithm passed to NumPy.

2.10.2. Series¶

Series.sort_index(ascending: bool = True, kind: str = 'mergesort') → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return a new Series ordered by the sorted Index.

Series.sort_values(ascending: bool = True, kind: str = 'mergesort') → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return a new Series ordered by the sorted values.

2.10.3. Frame¶

Frame.sort_index(ascending: bool = True, kind: str = 'mergesort') → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a new Frame ordered by the sorted Index.

Frame.sort_columns(ascending: bool = True, kind: str = 'mergesort') → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a new Frame ordered by the sorted Columns.

Frame.sort_values(key: collections.abc.Hashable, ascending: bool = True, axis: int = 1, kind='mergesort') → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a new Frame ordered by the sorted values, where values is given by one or more columns.

Deviations from Pandas

The default sort kind, delegated to NumPy sorting routines, is merge sort, a stable sort. In some versions of Pandas the default sort kind is quicksort.

2.11. Transformations & Utilities¶

The following utilites transform a container into a container of similar size.

2.11.1. Series¶

Series.isin(other) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return a same-sized Boolean Series that shows if the same-positoined element is in the iterable passed to the function.

Series.transpose() → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

The transpositon of a Series is itself.

Series.unique() → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Return a NumPy array of unqiue values.

Series.duplicated(exclude_first=False, exclude_last=False) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Return a same-sized Boolean Series that shows True for all b values that are duplicated.

Series.drop_duplicated(exclude_first=False, exclude_last=False)[source]¶

Return a Series with duplicated values removed.

2.11.2. Frame¶

Frame.isin(other) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a same-sized Boolean Frame that shows if the same-positioned element is in the iterable passed to the function.

Frame.transpose() → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a tansposed version of the Frame.

Frame.unique(axis=None) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Return a NumPy array of unqiue values. If the axis argument is provied, uniqueness is determined by columns or row.

Frame.duplicated(axis=0, exclude_first=False, exclude_last=False) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Series[source]¶

Return an axis-sized Boolean Series that shows True for all rows (axis 0) or columns (axis 1) duplicated.

Frame.drop_duplicated(axis=0, exclude_first: bool = False, exclude_last: bool = False) → package.public.static_frame.static_frame.Frame[source]¶

Return a Frame with duplicated values removed.

Deviations from Pandas

Pandas pd.DataFrame.duplicated() is equivalent to Frame.duplicated(exclude_first=True). Pandas pd.DataFrame.drop_duplicates() is equivalent to Frame.drop_duplicated(exclude_first=True).

2.12. Container Export¶

Methods for exporting alternative repesentations from Series and Frame.

2.12.1. Series¶

Series.to_pairs() → typing.Iterable[typing.Tuple[collections.abc.Hashable, typing.Any]][source]¶

Return a tuple of tuples of index label, value.

Series.to_pandas()[source]¶

Return a Pandas Series.

2.12.2. Frame¶

Frame.to_pairs(axis) → typing.Iterable[typing.Tuple[collections.abc.Hashable, typing.Iterable[typing.Tuple[collections.abc.Hashable, typing.Any]]]][source]¶

Return a tuple of major axis key, minor axis key vlaue pairs, where major axis is determined by the axis argument.

Frame.to_pandas()[source]¶

Return a Pandas DataFrame.
